sentences: Anabela Atijas (née Bukva; Serbo-Croatian Cyrillic: Анабела Атијас née Буква; born 26 January 1975), known mononymously as Anabela, is a Bosnian-Serbian pop singer.
section: N/A

sentences: She launched her career in 1993 as a part of the duo Funky G, together with her former husband Gagi Đogani.
section: N/A

sentences: The duo split in 2009 because Gagi Đogani was abusive in their marriage.
section: N/A

sentences: Anabela continued her career as a solo singer, and released her first solo album, Igra sudbine, on 21 July 2010 through City Records.
section: N/A
== Life and career ==

sentences: Life and career ==
section: == Life and career ==
== Life and career == | === 1975–1990: Early childhood ===
== Life and career == | === 1975–1990: Early childhood ===

sentences: Early childhood ===
section: == Life and career == | === 1975–1990: Early childhood ===

sentences: Anabela Bukva was born in Goražde, SR Bosnia and Herzegovina, SFR Yugoslavia to a Bosniak Muslim father Ahmed Bukva and Bosnian Serb mother Jadranka Polutak.
section: == Life and career == | === 1975–1990: Early childhood ===

sentences: Her parents filed for divorce when she was three or four years old.
section: == Life and career == | === 1975–1990: Early childhood ===

sentences: The divorce was finalized when she began first grade of primary school.
section: == Life and career == | === 1975–1990: Early childhood ===

sentences: It was initially argued in court that Anabela would live with her father because her mother did not have the financial capabilities to care for Anabela.
section: == Life and career == | === 1975–1990: Early childhood ===

sentences: The court did not favor this opinion, but could not make a decision.
section: == Life and career == | === 1975–1990: Early childhood ===

sentences: Instead, the matter was given to Anabela to decide with whom she would live after the divorce.
section: == Life and career == | === 1975–1990: Early childhood ===

sentences: Because of a strong connection with her father, Anabela chose to remain with her father.
section: == Life and career == | === 1975–1990: Early childhood ===

sentences: Anabela describes herself and her father as being a "dream team"; they were inseparable.
section: == Life and career == | === 1975–1990: Early childhood ===

sentences: She was immersed in music from an early age.
section: == Life and career == | === 1975–1990: Early childhood ===

sentences: Her father would play the guitar for her, and the two would often sing duets together.
section: == Life and career == | === 1975–1990: Early childhood ===

sentences: She grew up with her father's two half-brothers from her paternal grandfather's second marriage.
section: == Life and career == | === 1975–1990: Early childhood ===

sentences: The older half-brother is four years older than Anabela, and the younger Anabela's age.
section: == Life and career == | === 1975–1990: Early childhood ===

sentences: Because they were all close in age, Anabela viewed them as her brothers.
section: == Life and career == | === 1975–1990: Early childhood ===

sentences: She was a self-described tomboy, and practiced karate.
section: == Life and career == | === 1975–1990: Early childhood ===

sentences: She finished her primary education in Goražde, and decided to relocate to Sarajevo at the age of 13 for secondary education in foreign languages.
section: == Life and career == | === 1975–1990: Early childhood ===

sentences: She lived in Sarajevo for two years, having moved between thirteen apartments during her short stay.
section: == Life and career == | === 1975–1990: Early childhood ===

sentences: She has two paternal half-sisters, Ilda and Aida (born 1985), who is an actress.
section: == Life and career == | === 1975–1990: Early childhood ===
== Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===
== Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: During winter break in late 1990, Anabela left Bosnia for Switzerland with her boyfriend, Nikola.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: Shortly after they left, their home country Yugoslavia began breaking up and several wars started, including one in Bosnia.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: Nikola returned to Bosnia, as his parents had been left behind.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: He became one of the first victims of the war.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: Anabela remained in Switzerland for a short period, and could not return to Bosnia because of border closures.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: She had no family in Switzerland nor contact with family in Bosnia, so she decided to relocate to Belgrade.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: Looking for a normal life, she gained some footing in Belgrade through the help of Nikola's family.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: A refugee from Croatia hired Anabela to work as a secretary in his office.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: After seeing a commercial advertising for the opening of the Đogani Dance School, she decided to sign up for dance classes.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: Gazmen "Gagi" Đogani, a dance instructor at the Đogani Dance School, was attracted to Anabela and immediately offered to take her on a date.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: Anabela described the relationship as an instant love.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: The duo spent hours choreographing dances to Western songs by popular artists such as Bobby Brown, Michael Jackson and Whitney Houston.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: Gagi decided to create an all-girl music group in 1993.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: The duo split, both professionally and privately, in 2009.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: Anabela continued her career as a solo singer.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: Montenegrin singer Nenad Knežević Knez and Serbian rapper Milan 011 wrote a song for the group, called Samo u snu (Only in Dreams).
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: Knez questioned Gagi's choice of having many different girls performing in the group, instead opting to have just Anabela perform.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: Gagi agreed on a whim and asked Anabela to join his group, Funky G.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: Although liking the idea, she was reluctant to do it.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: The duo eventually recorded a video for the song Samo u snu.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: Having received an invitation to come, Anabela decided to move to Sweden to live with her mother.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: She gained refugee status in Sweden, and began attending school.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: In the meantime, Gagi replaced Anabela with another woman.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: Within a few months, Gagi began repeatedly calling Anabela during her stay in Sweden, informing her of the success of their single throughout the clubs in Serbia.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: Gagi begged Anabela to return to Serbia immediately to perform at a concert in the famed Sava Center.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: Anabela did not immediately believe Gagi, and remained skeptical.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: Gagi sent Anabela a banknote of 5,000 Deutsche Marks as proof that he was earning money on behalf of her own work.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: Still unconvinced, Anabela, by chance, watched a report on CNN on the nightlife of Belgrade's youth during a time of economic sanctions.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: Many different nightclubs were showcased in the report, and in several of them, Anabela heard the song she and Gagi had earlier made.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: Finally believing Gagi, she reluctantly agreed to come back despite having been awarded refugee status.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: Anabela was shocked by the celebrity status she had gained in Belgrade.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: The public started to associate Funky G with Anabela.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: In an effort to appease fans, Anabela decided to attend vocal schooling to improve her singing ability and provide vocals in subsequent Funky G releases.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: After the release of Funky G's second album in 1995, Anabela unexpectedly became pregnant.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: Gagi, after hearing the news, was indifferent about the pregnancy.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: However, after hearing the baby's heartbeat on the ultrasound, Gagi became excited about his first child.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: In preparation for the baby's delivery, Gagi and Anabela saved money to purchase an apartment of their own.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: Anabela gave birth to her daughter Luna in 1996.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: She later miscarried twins, and had trouble getting pregnant thereafter.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: She sought the help of fertility doctors, aiding her in becoming pregnant with her second daughter, Nina.
section: == Life and career == | === 1990–2005: Bosnian War and Funky G ===

sentences: === 2009–present: Breakup and solo career ===
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–present: Breakup and solo career ===

sentences: Marital problems between Anabela and Gagi became evident following Nina's birth in 2005.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–present: Breakup and solo career ===

sentences: After a long period of instability in the relationship, the marriage ended in April 2009 and Anabela subsequently left Funky G to start a solo career.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–present: Breakup and solo career ===

sentences: Anabela is currently married to a Bosnian Jewish businessman Andrej Atijas.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–present: Breakup and solo career ===

sentences: Atijas lived in Serbia where he studied, and his mother lives in Pančevo.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–present: Breakup and solo career ===

sentences: They have one daughter together, Blankica Atijas born 20 May 2013 in Sarajevo.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–present: Breakup and solo career ===

sentences: After living in Sarajevo for a year, Anabela returned to live in Belgrade.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–present: Breakup and solo career ===

sentences: Anabela released her first solo album, Igra sudbine (Game of destiny), on 21 July 2010 through City Records.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–present: Breakup and solo career ===

sentences: She has citizenship in both Bosnia and Herzegovina and Serbia.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–present: Breakup and solo career ===
